qas.question: What happens to the current when an inductive circuit is opened?

answers.text: the current through the inductance collapses quickly

qas.question: What happens to the voltage when an inductive circuit is opened?

answers.text: a large voltage across the open circuit of the switch

qas.question: What type of capacitor is used to make a path to bypass the contact points?
What is a typical system in which a snubber capacitor is found?
What type of capacitor absorbs radio frequency interference?
What happens to the current when an inductive circuit is closed?

plausible_answers.text: large voltage across the open circuit of the switch

qas.question: What happens to the voltage when an inductive circuit is closed?
What type of capacitor is used to make a path to not bypass the contact points?
What is a typical system in which a snubber capacitor is not found?
What type of capacitor dispenses radio frequency interference?

context: When an inductive circuit is opened, <a0_0>the current through the <b5_0>inductance collapses quickly<b5_0/><a0_0/>, creating <a1_0>a <b6_0>large voltage across the open circuit of the switch<b6_0/><a1_0/> or relay. If the inductance is large enough, the energy will generate a spark, causing the contact points to oxidize, deteriorate, or sometimes weld together, or destroying a solid-state switch. <a2_0><b7_0>A snubber capacitor<b7_0/><a2_0/> across the newly opened circuit creates a path for this impulse to bypass the contact points, thereby preserving their life; these were commonly found in <a3_0><b8_0>contact breaker ignition systems<b8_0/><a3_0/>, for instance. Similarly, in smaller scale circuits, the spark may not be enough to damage the switch but will still radiate undesirable radio frequency interference (RFI), which <a4_0>a <b9_0>filter capacitor<a4_0/> absorbs<b9_0/>. Snubber capacitors are usually employed with a low-value resistor in series, to dissipate energy and minimize RFI. Such resistor-capacitor combinations are available in a single package.
